Introduction 49 Biofilm formation is initiated when free swimming, planktonic cells contact a 50 surface. This contact serves as a signal that must be transmitted across the cell envelope 51 into the cytoplasm to initiate appropriate physiological changes to adapt to the biofilm 52 mode of growth (1). For many bacteria this initial surface contact is mediated through 53 motility appendages such as type IV pili (T4P) or flagella (2-8). Contact between these 54 appendages and the surface creates forces that are not normally present in planktonic 55 environments and can serve as a “surface signal” to the microbe (9). 56 Early work in Vibrio parahaemolyticus demonstrated that the signals encountered 57 during surface contact could be mimicked by increasing the load on the flagellum either 58 through changes in viscosity of the medium or by addition of antibodies specific to the 59 flagellum (10, 11). Recent work in Caulobacter crescentus demonstrated that holdfast 60 formation and DNA replication, which normally occurs during surface contact, could be 61 stimulated by increasing the load on Tad pili during retraction. Furthermore, the baseline 62 number of cells with a holdfast without prior pili obstruction was higher in mutants that 63 were unable to rotate their flagellum (2). Others have demonstrated that the flagellar 64 motor itself is able to sense surface contact to trigger c-di-GMP production leading to 65 holdfast synthesis (12). Together, these data indicate that bacteria use their surface 66 appendages to help sense surface engagement and indicate that impeding the motion (i.e., 67 retraction and/or rotation) of these appendages might serve as the proximal signal for 68 surface engagement. 69 Pseudomonas aeruginosa, like other organisms, utilizes T4P as well as its polar 70 flagellum to sense and traverse surfaces (3, 13-16). The cAMP binding protein Vfr then binds cAMP and activates genes 84 necessary for further surface adaptation, as well as for virulence (23, 24). 85 Recent work by Yarrington, Limoli and colleagues shows that the PilJ likely detects 86 phenyl soluble modulins via its periplasmic domain as a ligand to trigger signaling, a 87 finding that strongly suggests that PilJ can function like a classic MCP (25). Others have 88 recently uncovered the function of PilG and PilH in twitching motility and surface 89 adaptation (26, 27). In contrast, how surface engagement by T4P triggers cAMP signaling 90 in a PilJ-dependent manner is still an open question. A previous study showed that the 91 ligand binding domain (LBD) of PilJ is not required for surface-dependent cAMP 92 production, although the extent of cAMP induction is significantly reduced relative to the 93 WT (28).
